prose: The air in the Préfecture’s antechamber was stale with waiting. Across the desk, a clerk with eyes like filed stamps examined my dossier. “I see here in your own submission, Article 7-B, the required countersignature from the Sous-Préfet of the arrondissement is absent. A rather elementary oversight.” I felt the opportunity begin to lose its shape in my hands—to lose is to fail to keep, to feel a thing slip from your grasp into the void of bureaucracy. “But of course,” the clerk continued, not looking up, “the paperwork for such a replacement is notoriously… particular. One misplaced stamp, one incorrect form number, and the entire dossier collapses.” He finally lifted his gaze. “Your signature appears unsteady, madame. Perhaps you should take a moment in the antechamber.” Defeated, I retreated to the hall. A pair of officials passed me, their conversation a low murmur. “I can't believe we may see the Hexagon's new annex completed in my tenure,” said one. “Truly? So the central archive project may finally be approved?” replied the other before turning a corner. Their talk of grand projects only sharpened my own small failure. I needed a drink, but not here. To be in the Préfecture was to have the quality of being scrutinized, a specimen under glass. I fled to the streets, seeking the civil world—the civil sphere, applying to ordinary citizens, a realm of unregulated breath and un-stamped conversations. I found it in a dim café where a contact, Léo, was already waiting. “You look like you’ve been auditing ghosts,” he said, pushing a glass of wine toward me. It was sweet and cloying—sweet means having the characteristic taste of sugar, a comfort I couldn’t afford. “The matter is now closed,” I sighed, quoting the official dismissal. “Nonsense. The real way to get equipment?” Léo leaned in. “Find a bandit with a requisition form, relieve him of it, then have the armorer file the transfer paperwork. That's how it's done.” He smiled. “A glass to the health of our Republic!” I drank, the sweet wine now a bitter fuel. His plan was reckless, but it let a new possibility unfold—to let is to make it possible through a specific action for something to happen. It would require nerve. I would have to take a significant risk—to take is to carry out an action, regardless of consequence. “You’ll see,” I said, echoing the cryptic promise of the corridors. “The Hexagon is reviewing its policies.” Léo laughed. “Then may the forms be ever in your favor, Citizen.” We parted with the standard, ironic farewell: “Until we meet again, may your papers be in order and the roads remain open.” I stepped back into the twilight, my next move, at last, clear.

The Préfecture’s administrative sector was a maze of identical corridors, each one a mile of polished floor and echoing bureaucracy. To think was to doubt the system, and doubt was a luxury no one could afford. Inspector Valois stood close to his desk, the additional paperwork from the Salon incident forming a daunting tower. Additional means extra, and this pile felt like a condemnation.

His colleague, Manheim, leaned in, voice low. “Someone has requested an expedited termination review.” He tapped a file. “Rufio. Time to balance the ledger.”

Valois felt a cold weight settle in his stomach. “Let us ensure the paperwork is completed in red ink.”

Later, seeking clarity, he found the archivist Dumas in a cramped back room. A room is an area within a building enclosed by walls and floor and ceiling, and this one was a tomb for forgotten forms. Dumas was agitated, his usual composure shattered.

“I was only processing the paperwork,” Dumas whispered, eyes wide. “The Salon was a routine inspection—a formality. But the report... the casualty list... it doesn’t match the initial authorization. Someone altered the terroir assessment for that district.”

Valois grew interested. To be interested is to show curiosity or concern, and his was now fully engaged. “Who?”

“They’re saying it was a ‘procedural cascade.’ That the forms themselves triggered the containment failure. But I saw the original stamps. Madame Renard approved it. Inspector Valois countersigned. Then the archive copy... it’s different.” Dumas looked haunted. “I still can't process the Salon report. Madame Renard, Inspector Valois, the archivist Dumas... all gone.”

The revelation was very disturbing. Very is used as an intensifier, and the situation was now intensely perilous. Before Valois could respond, a gruff voice sounded from the doorway. It was Sergeant Lefevre from Logistics, his expression unreadable.

“Your file shows exceptional compliance ratings,” Lefevre said, “and the grapevine suggests you've already resolved several... delicate situations. Very well. Authorization granted.” He slid a sealed dossier across the desk. Then, his tone shifting, he added, “The real way to get equipment? Find a bandit with a requisition form, relieve him of it, then have the armorer file the transfer paperwork. That's how it's done.”

The advice was a stark contrast to administrative orthodoxy. Valois understood the message: the official path was closed. To survive, to uncover the truth, he would have to operate outside the very procedures he was sworn to uphold. The image of the altered forms burned in his mind. An image is an iconic mental representation, and this one—of forged stamps and red ink—was the key to everything. He would have to be resourceful. To be is to have the quality of existing in a certain state, and now, he would have to be a hunter.
